July 11-1927

Reference No. 24-1-5

Referring to your letter of 15 June regarding educational trip or picnic for older pupils of Roma Ladies Day School. This outing was held on the 3rd and I accompanied the teacher & pupils and the outing was enjoyed greatly by the pupils and I have no doubt they will benefit by it. We proceeded by Motor to Midland Port Methodist Church, visiting the docks and taking the pupils aboard the large vessels that were in Port at the time, also through the large grain elevators, and also other places of interest. Short essays were written by the pupils of their trip which I had excellent. Possibly you might consider giving a prize or some. In addition to the cost of Motor Bus which was 70¢, scenery expense by the teacher for food amounted to 5.13 and my outlay 1.73 making 3.86 in excess of the 24¢ allowed provided you will approve of these amounts & will counter sign on.

Sincerely,

[Signature]
C.S. Hudson
Secretary

N.B. page 2
We would like very much good quality cheesecloth for the girls to make white dresses for themselves for pageants, cantatas for school concert to be given about Nov. 1st. These would be kept for school use only, about 40 yards.

The simple tools are proving a boon to the boys. I am delighted at the interest in sewing, crochet &c taken by the girls. It seems to me that more time for this kind of thing would solve a number of the problems of this reserve, in that the girls would have added interests to fill their time.

Next year, the Sr. girls will be required to make underwear and I hope a simple dress for themselves.

One would need about 3 pairs of hands to do it all. If only there were an extra room and even a part-time teacher, to help with the hard work.

The ideal, it seems to me now, would be—
4 hrs per day academic work—3 hrs per day hand work—longer noon—breaks for Physical Culture.

However, another year will help to define the ideas.

The cause of any trouble here is idleness fostered by lack of training.

(Mrs) Jean Skeete,
Principal

Ottawa, July 15, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, giving a list of the supplies required for the use of the Rama Indian Day School at the beginning of the new academic year. In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

- 2 brooms
- 1 copper wash boiler
- 1 case Gillett's lye
- 2 rolls picture wire
- 2 boxes paper clips
- 1 axe
- 1 clothes line
- a quantity of soap and pearline.

You may have a post installed to attach the clothes line. You may also have the furnace overhauled and dampers with chains put in the pipes where required. In the purchase of the above supplies and repairs to the furnace, etc., you should see that no unnecessary expense is incurred and that the cost is kept down as low as possible.

I have also your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a list from the senior teacher showing the sewing material required by her. In reply I beg to say that you may incur an expenditure not exceeding $25.00 in the purchase of this material for the teaching of sewing, knitting, etc. It would be advisable to consult the teacher as to what is required, and you might arrange with her to purchase the material when the school re-opens. The above authorized amount should not be exceeded.

Please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the above authorized expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

A. S. Anderson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, July 15, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, furnishing a report on the visit made by the older pupils of the Rama Indian Day School to Midland and Port McNicoll. The Department is pleased that this trip was a success and enjoyed by the pupils. An account, covering the charges of the motor bus which conveyed the children on their visit, has already been received and paid. You may forward vouchers for the cost of the food given the pupils during the trip and for your personal outlay. Proper receipts should be attached and payment will then be made.

The essays written by the pupils, giving an account of their trip, have been received. I may say that the Department will allow a prize of $2.00 to the pupil writing the essay considered by yourself or the teacher as being the best and the sum of $1.00 to the second best. You may prepare and forward a voucher, properly certified, for these amounts. The names of the successful pupils should be stated on the voucher. The essays which you forwarded are returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

A. S. Anderson, Esq.,
Indian Agent
Longford Mills,

R.R. # Athelstey, Ont
July 4/27

Mrs. Russell T. Herring, Sup't Ed.
Dept'g Ind. Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

After being here a year, and putting my best thought and effort into the problems of this reserve, I am venturing to write to you personally concerning one or two matters that are possible solutions of perhaps the most serious problem of the lot.

But first of all, I want to thank the Department for the support, and prompt furnishing of supplies asked for. It has meant much to what I consider a very successful for the pupils. I have been experimenting to find out what appeals most and I trust a program can be worked out that will make for greater usefulness in the years to come.

The sewing and crocheting for the girls has kept everyone of them in school all year. But they want to make real clothing not just practice stuff. If we can get the material to make up, I shall...
thought that perhaps some of it could be sold to provide material for the next year. I have noted also that the older girls and some women are eager to learn new ways of earning a living so that they will not have to sell body and soul for clothes.

This brings me to a suggestion, that dawned in my mind, where a dance kept me awake most of the night of July 1st. I haven't seen the Agent yet to get his opinion and as I leave for my holiday as soon as the cheque arrives, I may not see him.

They tell me a new Council hall is to be built. Also that Mr. Orr recommended using material of the old one for the new building. The puzzle to provide ways and means for training the girls and women, without the expense of more buildings, was solved in my dreaming.

Would not the Department consider keeping the old Council Hall as part of the school unit for industrial purposes, due to provide adequate space for physical training in all kinds of weaving?

(a) I should like to see the girls taught basket weaving by one or two of the best workers in the reserve. It is becoming a lost art.

(b) Rug making could be added to the handicrafts.
with only a slight initial expense.

(c) The girls ought to have as part of their school course a simple practical course in cooking and cleaning.

A cook stove in the hall—such as most ordinary utensils—even makeshift ones—would be a means of splendid work here.

(d) A homemade workbench—a few tools—a few feet of lumber, some nails, glue etc., and the boys could get practical handcraft-making of furniture, practical arithmetic etc.

(e) Classes for women under the guidance of the teachers could do a little to elevate the moral tone by giving them something to do. There are a few who want to learn how to garden—do dairy work etc.—Some of the girls in school are intensely interested.

f. With Entrance classes there will be two more studying for next year—it's heavy work for one or even two—and immediately the salary is just ordinary teacher's salary—but Miss Wilcox and I are ready to put every bit of our energy and knowledge into the work here.
The chief problem here, is that through natural laziness emphasized by lack of definite training for any definite work, the people get into all kinds of mischief and are an ever increasing menace to the welfare of the community.

g. With the added space - the problem of training for School Concerts &c would be solved.

h. With all due deference to Mr. Orr, whom I was sorry to have missed by 10 minutes on his surprise visit here, the place and quietness of the school would be materially enhanced if the new Council Hall were built farther north on the present grounds, near the crossroads corner; and we need the nights rest if we are to carry the work here in the least adequately.

I hope that you will take this suggestion in the spirit in which it is given and consider ways and means of promptly saving this building for the school and women of this Reserve.

Yours truly,

Mrs. Jane Chickle, Prin.
Longford Hall
July 15, 1927

I enclose herewith a letter addressed to Mr. Russell & Co., handed to me by Mrs. Stickle, Principal Roma Indian Day School, which will explain itself regarding her suggestion that the present Council Hall be converted into a new one in order to be used for school purposes. I cannot agree to her suggestion that the present Council Hall is not safe and would not be advisable to use for school purposes provided a new hall is built possible. We could arrange in the basement a section that could be used for school work as set forth by Mrs. Stickle.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Roma Indian Reserve

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, October 31st, 1927.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Rama Indian Day School, states as follows:

"A cupboard large enough for general supplies in the senior room would permit the cupboard now in senior room to be moved to junior room for manual training, art and other supplies. Every classroom should have a cupboard for supplies. When the lights were put in near the front of the senior classroom, one should have been put in in centre of room".

If you approve of the Inspector's suggestion, you may arrange to have the cupboard in the senior room moved to the junior room and arrange to have a cupboard large enough to contain the general supplies installed in the senior room. It is thought that it would be cheaper to have this cupboard built locally than to purchase same. I shall be pleased if you will consult the teacher as to the type of cupboard that would be satisfactory, and forward an estimate of the cost of having same built.

I have also to request that you will state the probable cost of installing a light in the senior classroom, as recommended by the Inspector.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, regarding the installation of a cupboard in the junior room at the Rama Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that a cupboard of the same size as the one at present in use in the senior room would be satisfactory for the purpose. We note that you estimate that a cupboard of the same size could be placed in the junior room at a cost of $35, and you may arrange to have this done. It would not, therefore, be necessary to make any change in the cupboard in the senior room, and the new cupboard would be for the use of the junior room. You should see that locks and keys are provided. When this cupboard has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Regarding the installing of a light in the centre of the senior classroom, the Department, in view of your recommendation, considers that it is not necessary to take any further action in this matter at the present time.

Relative to the water getting into the basement, I beg to say that this matter will receive consideration, and you will be further advised.

Sir,

Something further will have to be done with regards to the water getting into the basement of the Roma Indian Day School. I was in hopes that when we put a new floor in the furnace part that the trouble would cease, in that part at least to a certain extent, but in that part used by the teachers it is very bad. I have examined it on different occasions but cannot understand how it comes in. And I consider that some practical person should investigate the trouble and advise what is best to be done. So much water causes a dampness and it is not healthy for teacher or pupils.

Yours truly,
M. Anderson
Roma Indian Reserve

Feb. 14, 1928.

Dear Mr. Anderson,

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, regarding the water getting into the basement of the Rama Day School, you will remember that when I visited the school last year we arranged to put in a new concrete floor in order to drain the water to the outlet in the basement floor. The water from this point to be carried to the well at the front of the building and a pump provided to pump the water from the well. It would be very difficult to keep the water from seeping through the walls of the basement, but this summer when I am at Rama in connection with the Council Hall I will discuss the matter further with you.

Yours very truly,

H. Gurney Gill,
Architect for the Department.

July 6, 1929

Reference No. 74-1-5

Referring to your letter of 1st June regarding wells at School & Council Hall. I had the water in the well at the School all pumped out and the inside also cleaned out. I took samples of the School and Council Hall water and had them tested. The report I received according to the Provincial Analysts is... The water from the well at the School is bad and the drinking of it should be prohibited. The water from the Hall pump is OK. It is a question of by cleaning out the well again and washing the stone work with Chloride of lime it will be much better but it is worth a try. But if the soil through which the water comes into the well is infected the treatment is worthless.

Immediately upon receiving the report I went direct to the School pump and placed a notice prohibiting the use of the water and at the same time disconnected the pump so that it cannot be used. Kindly let me have your satisfaction in the matter.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, relative to the request of the teacher of the Rama Indian Day School to be supplied with a portable gramaphone for use in the school.

Ottawa, December 13, 1930.

Sir:

Miss Cousins, travelling nurse, who recently visited the Rama Indian Day School, recommends that equipment be provided to enable the pupils to wash their hands at school. She states that some of the children remain all day at school and have no means of washing and that others come dirty.

The Department will approve of your arranging for the purchase of a suitable washbasin, 6 cakes toilet soap and a small quantity of towelling, and, if same are required, a few steel combs and an inexpensive mirror. The teachers should see that this equipment is properly taken care of and used by the pupils. After the purchase of the above has been made, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, informing the Department that the roof of the Rama Indian Day School requires repairing in order to prevent leakage. In this connection I would point out that you have not stated the work necessary to place the roof in good condition.

Our funds this year are extremely limited, and it will not be possible to authorize the expenditure required in supplying the material and labour in putting on a new roof. Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a communication from Miss Swordfeger, senior teacher of the Rama Indian Day School, requesting that she be allowed to teach her class two Saturdays before the Christmas vacation and close the school on December 19th, next.

In reply I have to say that the Department desires that this school be kept in operation until four o'clock on the afternoon of December 22nd, next, and that no teaching be carried on during Saturdays. Please inform the teacher of the Department's requirements and also that the date for reopening the school after the Christmas holidays is to be on the morning of Tuesday, January 5th, next.

MEMORANDUM:

I visited the Rama Indian Day School on the 17th ultimo and found everything satisfactory. The attendance is irregular mostly due to colds and slight ailments. Seven pupils were absent on the day I was there.

The buildings are in a good state of repair. The front steps will later on need a few boards replaced. The Agent will have this attended to when it becomes necessary.

Apparently both teachers are giving good service and getting along very well with the parents. The Indians I talked with, all spoke very highly of them.

The walls of both classrooms look bare. Could you let them have six wall pictures each for the two rooms? There is a need for four wire window screens, two for each room. Nothing in this way has ever been provided and it is very annoying, particularly in the summer time, when the windows have to be opened, to have the classrooms full of flies.

If the funds at your disposal will bear this small expenditure, I would recommend that Agent Anderson be advised to get four screens made right away.

INSPECTOR.
Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Rama Indian Day School, has recommended that four screens be provided for the windows of the classroom — two for each classroom. There are twelve pictures in the set, and six should be placed in each classroom.

Dear Sir:

Following up our conversation re draining basement at Indian School, I looked over the situation, and I would recommend taking up the cement around the two wet sides of the school, placing weeping tile underneath laid in fine crushed stone, and putting the cement back again, and piping the drainage to a sump hole. I would dig this hole in the ground and cement it and install an automatic electric sump pump, which would keep the water pumped a foot below the floor, and pipe it to a suitable point where it would flow by gravity outside. This pump is worth ninety ($90.00) dollars. I will install it, doing the electric wiring, laying the tile and putting fresh cement back again as it is now, making and cementing sump hole for $60.00. This would make a total of $150.00 and I would leave everything in good order.

MEMORANDUM

I inspected the Rama Agency on the 14th and 15th instant and beg to submit the following report.

Day School

The classroom walls and ceilings are badly in need of painting. The plaster on the north wall of the junior room is badly damaged by water leaking through the roof.

Repairs to the roof have been made from time to time with little success. It has done service for 22 years and further attempts at repairing it are useless. The only solution is a new roof as soon as funds are available.

The front steps of the building need repairs. Two steps are broken and should be replaced by new planks.

The upstairs rooms of the teachers' residence should be re-decorated as soon as funds are available. The walls are very dirty and shabby from rain seeping through the roof.

Thos. McGoogin,
Inspector.
Ottawa, December 7, 1935.

Dear Sir,-

In a report regarding his recent visit to the Rama Indian Day School, Inspector McGookin states that the plaster on the north wall of the junior room is badly damaged by water. If you consider it advisable to have this repaired, you may do so during the Christmas holidays.

Mr. McGookin also states that the front steps need repairs. Please have this matter receive your early attention.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

March 13th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

Owing to the recent heavy rains the basement in the Rama Indian Day School has become flooded.

On the evening of March 11th, Miss Swerdleger telephoned to me that the water was coming in very badly. I immediately got in touch with Mr. A.R. Payne, of Orillia and arranged with him to have the water removed.

I visited the School on the morning of the 12th and found the water had risen to about 4 feet, putting out the furnace, with the result that the School rooms were too cold for the pupils to remain in School, and I instructed the Teachers to dismiss their classes until such time as the trouble is overcome and the furnace can be started.

This morning the water had again risen to yesterday's depth, and consulting Mr. Payne he stated the only thing to do is to keep on pumping until the trouble is overcome. The School is still closed.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Agent,
Rama Indian Reserve.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Longford Mills, Ont.
March 17th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

In further reference to my letter of the 13th inst. regarding the water in the basement of Rama Indian Day School, it has been necessary to keep pumping the water until this morning, when the electric pump started and I expect it will be able to keep the water down, unless the flow into the basement is again as much as the last few days, the pump was not large enough to carry off all the water, hence it rose and put the pump out of order.

Where the water entered the basement could not be located, around the School the ground is raised, and no snow within 15 feet of the School wall. There is a down pipe from the roof at the North East of the School, which may be the cause of the trouble, and I would recommend that it be altered. The pipe from the roof runs down into the ground, close beside the wall of the School, coming down from the roof about half way down is a tin pipe connecting to an iron pipe about 10 feet in length, and this iron pipe goes down into the ground, and how the water is disposed of then I do not and could not find out, possibly if you have the plans of the School when it was built they will show. However I would recommend that this pipe into the ground be done away with, and made that the water be drained off on the surface. Immediately where the pipes enter the ground there is a settlement, as if something has given away.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

reference No. 24-1-5

On Friday 27th inst., the water again came into the basement of the Rama Indian Day School, about 4 p.m. It was coming in very fast, and as I was unable to get Mr. Payne to come out with pump, and pump the water out, I put three Indians to work to bale, and endeavour to keep the water down so as to prevent it rising and putting the sump pump out of business, about 7 p.m. The Electric current in the district went off, and when it came on again the Sump pump would not work, about 9 p.m. I took the men off the job as they were unable to keep the water down, as Mr. Payne's outfit for pumping was on another job, he could nothing on Saturday. So as to be able to have School open on Monday, I arranged with Mr. Payne to work on Sunday, which he did, and about 6 p.m. the water was all out again and the sump pump working.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, regarding the reshingling of the roof and the painting of the Rama Indian Day School building and giving an estimate of the cost.

As you were informed, the amount available to carry out the work at this school is $375. It is noted that you estimate the cost of the shingling to be $360 - in which event, there will be no funds to provide for the painting of the building.

The Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase, from firms on the approved list, of the shingles and other materials required to reshingle the roof. You may have the work carried out by Indian labour, under your supervision. Please keep proper time sheets, in triplicate, of the labour employed, and, if requested the Department would send you an advance for the amount you require to pay the labour. You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the shingles, nails and other material used. I would request that you arrange to have the work completed during the summer holidays.

It is considered that the painting of the building can stand over for another year, as we are unable to provide any funds in excess of the amount as stated above, that was appropriated for this school,

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent inspection of the Rama Agency.

The one - 2 class - Indian Day school was visited and conditions found very satisfactory. Average attendance is very good and the pupils are making good progress. They look healthy, clean and tidy. Cod Liver Oil is given daily in the class rooms. All pupils have been vaccinated up to date. Sewing, mending, and knitting are taught in the senior room. The class rooms are clean, comfortable and well ventilated.

The class room walls and ceilings are badly in need of redecorating. The upstairs rooms of the teacher's residence also need this attention. The walls have got discolored and shabby from a leaky roof. The new roof and painting of the outside wood work has added very much to the appearance of the building.

Thos. McGookin.
Inspector.

Dear Sir:

Reference No. 24-1-5

I have again to report that the sump pump in the basement of the Rama Indian Day School again went out of working order, and it was necessary that I secure the services of an electrician to attend to it immediately. An account of the water running into the basement, I was able to have it attended to; the meter in the pump required to be taken out and repaired, and while the meter was being repaired, another meter was left temporarily in the pump.

The walls of the School basement have been examined by an engineer and his report is, that in his opinion the only way to stop the water coming through the walls is to dig down to the depth of the walls all around the school, and then place a good covering of tar on the walls, and also tile all around.

Yours truly,

In compliance with your request I am sending you the bill for work done at the Rama School, also an explanation regarding the condition of the furnace.

We found on tearing down the furnace that the firepot and the cast radiator were so badly warped out of shape that it was impossible to put on the new combustion chamber, so we had to take the old casting back to town and patch it before replacing it. Now this will only last for a short time but we hope it will see you through the rest of the winter.

If you intend fixing up this furnace in the spring it will mean purchasing new firepot, combustion chamber, and radiator which is nearly the whole furnace.

As I pointed out in my previous letter this furnace is too small for the school and has to be fired too heavily to get the rooms to the required temperature, and as
In consequence, the furnace is burnt out prematurely. You will have the same trouble again if you still use this furnace.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill

I beg to submit the following report covering my visit to Rama Agency on May 1st and 2nd.

Schools:

School was found clean and tidy with orderly classrooms. Miss Graham and Miss McNeill interviewed, both seem competent teachers. Agent's attention was drawn to absence of individual drinking cups.

Repairs are necessary to outside toilet and to board fence in play ground estimated cost $35.00. Repairs are also necessary to front platform steps of school - estimated cost approximately $25.00. The platform and steps are not used, as side entrances are open, but have an unsightly appearance from the road and mar the appearance of an otherwise fine school building.

W.S. Arneil,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,

January 21st, 1942

Dear Sir:

As previously reported a number of children in the Rama school are infected with itch and impetigo. The known infected children have been sent home. I had Dr. Brown make an inspection of the pupils on Monday and he reports that the general cleanliness is not good and it is considered advisable to provide soap and paper towels for use at the school as sending these dirty children home for a clean up has not proved very effective. With this in view and in order to get started without delay, I have purchased a few paper towels and a bar of medicated soap.

I am of the opinion that liquid soap would be the most sanitary and satisfactory if a container can be purchased. Kindly advise if it is in order to purchase towels, soap and etc. required to carry out this plan.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant with reference to installing paper towels and liquid soap in the Rama Indian Day School. As you have been informed, Mr. Doucet of this Branch will visit the Rama School at the end of this week and you should discuss the matter further with him.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. H.J. Featherston,
Indian Agent,
Longford Mills, Ont.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

February 21st, 1942

Dear Sir:

Reference: 24-1-5

In reply to your letter of 13th instant, I have to advise that no noticeable improvement has resulted from carrying out the suggestions of Mr. Doucet in regard to the furnace in Rama Indian Day School.

There is not sufficient circulation of air to heat the rooms in cold weather and in my opinion it never will be satisfactory until an air fan unit is installed. I have had expert advice to this effect. This could have been done at the time the new furnace was installed in 1938 at a cost of about $75.00.

Yours truly,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada in which it is intimated that one of their officials was informed by Mr. Hayward, teacher of the Rama School, that the latter considered that the children were suffering from lack of proper food and it has been suggested that a midday meal should be supplied.

I wish to refer to your letter of October 19th in regard to furnace in Rama Indian Day School.

It has not been easy to get anyone to even look at an out-of-town job of this sort but yesterday Mr. Jack Oatway, a plumber from Orillia, who seems to know his business, came out and gave the furnace and system a looking over. As the repairs required are very much beyond anything known or thought of at the time of Mr. Phelan's visit, I am making a report and asking instructions.

The fire pot is burned through and has to be replaced and the grates are also ruined and have to be replaced. I made the inspection with Mr. Oatway and discussed with him the cause and remedy. In the first place the air doesn't circulate sufficient to heat the building and in an effort to do so, fires are made so hot that no furnace will stand it for long. Mr. Oatway says that the heat just sits over the furnace. The situation is made worse by the sort of coal that we are now compelled to use which burns up quickly and hot and also by a fireman not too competent.

The circulation can be increased somewhat by adding another cold air pipe to each room and taking it into the furnace a little differently at an estimated cost of $75.00 plus the cost of the castings (grates and firepot).
He strongly recommends the installation of a forced circulation system by electric fan. He estimates that this will cost $300.00 plus cost of castings. He also recommends an electric "janitor" to control the drafts at an additional cost of $37.50. He considers this particularly advisable in this case where one has to contend with an incompetent or careless fireman.

I think myself, that we will never get satisfaction until there is a forced circulation and the saving in coal will be considerable and the life of the furnace greatly increased.

As previously intimated, no one is looking for work or business but Mr. Catway has stated that he will undertake to do the job in the Christmas holidays if given the instructions immediately so that he can place his orders.

H.J. Featherston
Indian Agent, Rama Agency.

P.S.
There is no certainty that the firepot will permit the operation of the furnace until Christmas but it is hoped that it can be done.

Ottawa, February 16, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

We have had a great deal of trouble with the furnace in the two-room school at the Rama Reserve. The firepot was burned through and had to be replaced, and when the agent arranged for the inspection of the furnace by an expert it was found that the air did not circulate sufficiently to heat the building. Owing to the difficulty of securing expert advice, it was late in the year 1944 before definite information was available, and as the necessary labour could then be secured, the work covered by the attached voucher was authorized. It would be appreciated if you would issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows:- 421-76-10-691.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Encl.
Ottawa, February 23, 1945.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR DOREY,

Some weeks ago Reverend Doctor Dorey suggested that a midday meal be served at the Rama Indian Day School. We wrote to the Indian Agent and in reply he pointed out that in his opinion there was no necessity for serving a midday meal as all the children go home for lunch and none have to walk more than a mile. This information was conveyed to Rev. Dr. Dorey, but he has written again as follows:-

"Following our conversation, would you take up with Dr. Moore or Dr. Falconer the possibility of their looking into the advisability of arranging for noonday lunches or other means of improving the diet standards of the Rama Indians. This would, of course, mean a preliminary examination of the need of such improvement."

On the occasion of the next visit of either Dr. Falconer or yourself to the Rama Reserve, it would be appreciated if you would review the matter mentioned above.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON RAMA INDIAN AGENCY

The heating of the Day School has been much improved since the changes and repairs to the furnace.

H.J. Featherston,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

The exceedingly high wind that we experienced a few days ago blew the board fence that was in front of the girls toilet at Rama School down, posts and all. The toilets also require squaring up and repairing. Kindly send me an advance of $30.00 to cover the labour costs of the repairs required. Some new building material will be required also.

H.J. Featherston
Indian Agent, Rama Agency.

I would refer to my letter of April 11th in regard to damage to the board fence around the toilets at Rama Day School. The advance of $30.00 has been received but I have not as yet done anything about it. Mr. Hayward has suggested that if these toilets were moved, one to each side of the lot, benefit would result in that the boys would not hang around the toilets so much.

Extract from Inspector Bolingbroke's report on the Rama Indian Day School, May 20th, 1943. (Senior Room). Original on 24-1-6.

I would like to submit the following detail for improving school conditions:

(a) School grounds should be cleaned up and beautified. This school should set an example to the whole community.

(b) The building needs painting, inside and out.

(c) Proper electric lighting should be installed throughout the building.

(d) There should be some means of driving good warm air into the class rooms and exhausting foul air.

(e) Properly equipped inside toilets should be installed and if possible, there should be running water in the school building.

(f) There should be a definite system of supplying textbooks and work materials within a short time so that the particular needs of this school could be filled. The present system seems to give little leeway for supplying local needs.

(g) The cost of heating this school could be lowered if it were properly insulated.
July 20, 1948.

With reference to your letter of July 20th file 24—I-5(E.I) and more particularly the last sentence in regard to installing electricity in Rama Day School, I wish to report that there is electricity in the school but the installation is most inadequate. In the class rooms there are three lights only, at intervals across in front of the blackboard. The kitchen has a six drop light from the ceiling, no switch and no base plug. The same is true of the living room and the two bedrooms. The basement is much the same.

The Hydro-Electric Power Commission render a service, on request, in respect to the lighting of schools in the Province and I submitted a plan of the school (main floor) and asked their advice. They prepared a detailed plan which I am enclosing for your attention.

I went over the building with an electrician who has been doing some work herabouts and gave him the plans in order that he might prepare an estimate of the cost of a proper installation. This man failed to submit an estimate saying that he was unable to get quotations on suitable fixtures and just recently returned the plans. It may be that someone with a larger and better connection would proceed with the job but before contacting anyone else, you should review the whole thing and advise.

If the school is rewired, I am afraid that there is little of the present wiring that can be made use of in the new job. I would suggest that switches and base plugs be put in the kitchen, living room and bedrooms, the basement properly wired and possibly lights over the outside doors. I would suggest that either flourescent or Semi-direct lights
as shown on Plate 2 in group four be used in the classrooms. The fluorescent lights require much less current. It might well be that a 350 watt would do in place of the 500 watt if the semi-direct is used.

I would say that the job would probably run to five or six hundred dollars but this is only a guess.

Kindly advise and return plans.

H.J. Featherston
Indian Agent, Rama Agency.

- Size No. 1 for Adults,

Sir:

I would beg to advise you that after making an inspection of the River Settlement Indian Day School, I would recommend that a new roof be put on this school this Summer as the present roof is not in good shape and the shingles are loose and badly warped and it will not be long before it will do considerable damage to the interior of the school. In reference to the roof, I would believe that a good grade of arrow-lock shingle put on over the cedar shingle would make a satisfactory roof, providing the cedar shingles were all nailed down well before the arrow-locks were laid. These repairs could be done by Indian day labor.

Sir—

I would beg to advise you that the following repairs are needed at the River Settlement Indian Day School, Caradoc Reserve and should be done during the coming Summer holidays,

2 pieces timber 3" X 12" X 5' for repair of porch steps.
1 plane a glass 15 X 30.
The present windows need re-puttying.
1 pair of door knobs.
Paint or muresco the walls and ceiling of the class-room and replace any damaged plaster, before painting.

Last Summer a new roof was put on this School, but previous to this being done some little damage was done to the plaster and now that the roof is in good shape, repairs should be made to the plastering and then a coat of muresco applied. The woodwork in the school class room is in good condition. The total cost of this work should not exceed in the vicinity of $50.00, if only one coat of muresco applied, which I would believe to be enough at present.

Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

It is considered that one coat of muresco would be sufficient to be applied after the repairs to the plaster are carried out. This work should be performed during the summer holidays and, when completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Sir;-

I would beg to advise you that the following repairs are needed at the River Settlement Indian Day School of this Agency and that they should be made during the coming Summer holidays.

New bolt and lock to swing small gate at entrance to the school grounds.
Hook for door of the girls outhouse.
Repair school door lock or replace the same if necessary.
Three new blinds for the class room.

Sir;

I would beg to advise you that the following supplies and repairs are needed at the River Settlement Day School of this Agency and that these could be attended to during the coming Summer vacation.

2 locks for present cupboards,
3 catches for the elevation of the classroom windows,
12 feet of 6" cornice for that burnt by school boy.

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. Philip Phelan.

In company with Mr. McKnight of the Surveys and Engineering Branch of the Department, an inspection was made of the River Settlement Indian Day School of Caradoc Agency and the following repairs and materials are recommended for this school:

- A sheet galvanized flashing to repair chimney leak at an estimated cost of $2.50
- 6 screens for windows at an estimated cost of $3.60
- 1400 ft. Ten-Test - estimated cost $28.00
- 500 ft. strapping - estimated cost $7.50
- 100 ft. cove moulding - estimated cost $2.00
- 1 panel door with frame and oak sill (3'4" x 6'8") at an estimated cost of $2.50
- Locks and hinges at an estimated cost of $2.50
- 4 gal. of paint estimated cost $15.00
- Oil, turpentine and brushes - estimated cost $5.00
- Nails - estimated cost $4.25
- 1 pane of glass 14" x 31" and three-eighths inches, putty and glaze at an estimated cost of 75 cents.
- Exterior painting, 5 gals. of paint, oil, turpentine, etc. at an estimated cost of $25.00
- Labour - estimated cost $80.00

This is only an estimate and the total cost would run in the vicinity of $256.60 and would put this building in proper condition for a number of years.

The building is over 50 years old and it would be necessary to remove all plaster from walls and replace it with Ten-Test, as, on account of the condition of the plaster, it is dangerous to the pupils.

As this building is so old and not knowing what difficulties may arise when repairs are being made, I would ask the authority of the Department to purchase from local firms on the approved list the necessary materials for these repairs, to whom it is possible to return any unused materials after repairs are completed.

When this authority is granted, a cheque for $80.00 for payment of wages should be sent forward.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

I have made a tour of the Indian Day Schools of the Caradoc Agency and submit herewith a report as to repairs that I think are at this time necessary.

XX XX XX

RIVER SETTLEMENT

Both exterior and interior decorating are badly needed. This School is dull, dirty and dismal and does not lend itself to good teaching. In fact it should be rebuilt. However, $250.00 spent on it would perhaps brighten it up.

This report is submitted with a view to laying before you for consideration, repairs which I think are necessary and should be given every possible consideration. For convenience the listed repairs are in order of priority. You will appreciate the fact that we are already in the second month of summer holidays. It would therefore be appreciated, should you consider the suggested repairs, that this Office be advised as soon as possible.

Geo. W. Down, INDIAN AGENT.

During a recent visit and inspection of the River-Settlement School, my attention was drawn to the condition of the wood shed. It is in a bad state of repair and needs re-shingling. I have measured the building and estimate that it will take five squares to cover it. The approximate cost is estimated at,

5 sqs of No.1 5x shingles at $7.60 - $38.00
50 lbs of shingle nails at .10 - $5.00

$38.50
labour $20.00

$ 58.50

I would recommend that this work be done before school re-opens.

There are also a number of minor jobs around the school and grounds, such as, anew board here and there, new glass and new fence posts etc; amounting to perhaps, $20.00 which will be taken care of before school reopens.

Geo W. Down,

River Settlement

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the River Settlement School on the 27th ultimo Inspector Sexton states that the work at the school is handicapped by lack of tools and materials for making things.

Our funds for the purchase of such articles are rather limited. However, last year we allowed $20.00 for each school. We will endeavour to do the same for the academic year 1938-39. You might communicate with me in regard to this matter early in August.

It would be well to consult the teachers of the various schools before they leave for their holidays in order that you can ascertain from them what additional equipment of an inexpensive character they would suggest being secured.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,

Sir,

I beg to report that Miss Mary Pace, teacher of the Ryerson Indian School, has tendered her resignation, the same to take effect on the 30th June.

I beg to recommend that I be authorized to offer the position to Mr. B.M. Jacobs, teacher of the Harvey Inlet School. Mr. Jacobs has not communicated with me on the subject but as he is an active energetic young man and as the Ryerson School is in need of such a teacher, I venture to recommend his transfer.

If my recommendation is approved, it will be necessary in the event of Mr. Jacobs' acceptance of the offer to get a new teacher for the Harvey Inlet School.

I have the honor to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA 17th April, 1897

EXAMINED
SCHOOL BRANCH.

Last Thursday morning the new Indian school at the Upper Village on Parry Island was formally opened. On the invitation of Indian Superintendent Alec Logan, Mr. J. D. Ridgeway, Deputy Inspector of Public Schools, Rev James Binnie, St. Andrew's Church, Rev W. T. Bunt, Baptist Church, and Mr. Wm. Ireland, Editor of The North Star, accompanied the Superintendent to Parry Island. The scholars, headed by their teacher Miss Munro marched from the old school to the new and in the presence of a number of the parents and friends and the children Mr. Logan opened the proceedings.

In a brief speech he pointed out that the new school and teachers house had cost about $3,500 exclusive of the seats and fittings, and was in every respect a modern and model building. It was heated throughout by a furnace, had modern ventilation, plenty of light and was a sign of the progressive Indians were making, as well as a credit to the Band. He wanted every boy and girl on Parry Island to attend school regularly and pointed out the advantages of a good education. Mr. Moore, the School Inspector, next spoke and dwelt on the parents' importance of the children attending school regularly. They had row a fine school, a first class teacher in Miss Munro who was doing great improvement. Rev. Mr. Bunt was the next speaker and he was followed by Rev. Mr. Ireland. Chief Megis addressed the school both in Indian and English as did Rev. D. Menominee, the Indian Missionary and Mr. James Binnie. He recounted the fact that Mr. Ireland had been present at the opening of the old Skene school at the Lower Village, the Ryerson school just closed and now the new school. Mr. Ireland was asked to say a few words and he referred to the fact that he had been present at the opening of all three schools on Parry Island, and about thirty years ago he had named the school after the third Indian Superintendent, Captain Skene. The new school was erected by Mr. J. D. Ridgeway and was a very fine school of comfort and convenience. The proceedings closed by singing the National Anthem.
D. L. MacLean
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

To the Secretary,
Indian Dept., Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

I have just seen Mr. Logan, the Indian Agent and he showed me a letter from the department, at which I was surprised and also very much hurt, at the report Inspector Moore must have sent you of the condition of this school and my work. It is true I had a small school Jan. Feb. & March and I gave him the reasons for it. But the chief reason was the weather conditions. I had trouble with a couple of the Indians which also had some effect. I gave him these two reasons.

As soon as the weather and road were favourable, I visited the homes, and they told me, the weather had been so bad, these roads drifted, children tightly clad, they could not send them.
Now, I did not intend writing to the Department. I do not want to hurt or make trouble, or injure anyone. But since reading your letter I feel I must write in defense of myself.

Last Oct. James Walker and David S. Wing, two Indians of the Island, King is late teacher of the school. Truant officer and Policeman. Two old men as full of mischiefness as they are full of years. These men made up their minds they were going to turn the teacher out (as they called it) and get a Mr. Patridge who belongs to the island to take the school after him. They called a meeting, talked matters over, trying in every way to find a complaint. They asked the Chief to write to the Department, asking for a change of teacher. He told them he could not without a reason for my leaving. A certain first friend man friend of mine from Parry Sound, used to visit me. This James Walker said, "Can't we say something about the teacher and this man who visits the teacher?" So true and then they started a slander. As soon as I heard of it, I went to the Chief. He said he had nothing to do with it.
Then he told me just what I have told you. I also had a talk with Mr. King and Mr. Logan, and told them both what I thought of their actions. They only infuriated them more than ever; since they have never ceased to undermine me and my work. I asked Mr. Logan about it, and asked if I should report them. He said no. The quietest way was the best. When Inspector Moore came to visit the school, I asked him the same question. He said the same as Mr. Logan. I would not have written now, only I felt as I said before I must defend myself.

I would have left the school at once, had I been free to do so. As if these men had come to me as they should have done, and told me they would like a change, and given me time to get out. As it is, I had all my winter supplies in, also the furniture in the house belongs to me. You can see the offence & inconvenience. I never have been put to in leaving at that time. I told the Chief then I would leave at midsummer. I take Mr. Logan the same, also the Inspector, everyone on the island knows I am leaving them.
and I am surprised you have not been informed of the same. When the Inspector was here he also advised me to leave.

At the end of June I send in my resignation to Mr Logan.

My school since Easter has been very good, you cannot get the children to attend regular. I have worked hard and faithful. I am satisfied in that I have done my duty. I have been here for three years and a half and a change will be just all round.

Sincerely yours,

Frances E. Meant.

Dear Sirs:

I would like to know when the Indian language and the English language is supposed to be used on these Indian reserves.

Some of them will not talk English to me when they know I cannot understand Indian in their public meetings when the chief asks the missionary and another teacher from another school to speak in English they speak in Indian.

Since this I have forbidden the children to speak Indian at school. I go out to play with them so as to check them and my attendance goes up now as high as 58 with 43 on the...

I may say that why I want them to talk English around the school is to get them to understand it as that is why the children do not get along better at school. There are a few who can talk English and they are my best pupils.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,-

With reference to the letter addressed to the Prime Minister by Miss Watson, teacher of the Ryerson School on Parry Island, I beg to say that Miss Watson, who took charge of this school on September 11th, last, is the holder of a limited Third Class Certificate for Ontario and has had two years experience in teaching. She is twenty-one years old and is allowed a salary at the rate of $550.00 per annum, with a teacher's residence provided.

Mr. J. L. Moore, Public School Inspector, who visited the school on the 30th of November, last, reported that "Miss Watson has been very successful for the short time she has been in this school and deserves great credit for the way in which she has induced the children to attend school."

Apparently she made a good start, as the Agent also reported that when he visited the school on the 11th of October he found everything very satisfactory and a good attendance, and he recommended that more seats be purchased.
On the 12th of December she applied for an increase of salary, but she was informed that the Department regretted that it was unable to comply with her request, as, owing to the war, the funds at its disposal were limited.

On the 5th of February Miss Watson wrote the Department complaining that the caretaker was neglecting his duties and expressing her views pretty freely about affairs on Parry Island. She accused the caretaker of stealing things out of the school and said that, if the Department was willing to put up with this state of affairs, she was not and she would have to leave and get another school.

She also brought up the matter of the use of the telephone and complained that she had been asked to pay ten cents for the use of it. A copy of her letter was sent to the Agent, who was asked for a report.

She wrote again on February 13th, renewing her complaints against the caretaker and also found fault with the Agent, Chief and Missionary. In this letter she says that, "I cannot tell you in plain enough language what he (the caretaker) is like. You certainly would not like to hear them from a girl, the words that it takes to say what he is like. The Indian Agent has the gaul to tell me to put up with a man like this but I have had hell on earth long enough caused by him. You will certainly agree with me that this is not a fit place for a girl with people like this at the head. As I have said."
said before and which I will stick to, that if something is not done soon they will have to get a new teacher for the Ryerson Indian School, Parry Island.

On the 11th of March, the Agent, in reply to the Department's request for a report on Miss Watson's complaints, wrote saying that he was very much disappointed in Miss Watson, as he was under the impression that she was going to make a good teacher and that she would get along well with the Indians, especially as she had her mother keeping house for her. He stated that no meetings were held in the school-house of any kind and as for the use of the telephone, there is no charge for her or any members of the band for local calls. In reference to her complaints regarding the cleaning of the school he states that he interviewd the caretaker and the missionary and they say that on the Saturday complained of it was Nomination Day, they also had a funeral that day and, as it was very cold, they decided to leave the scrubbing of the school until the Monday afternoon. When Miss Watson decided not to open school on Monday morning they scrubbed it out in the morning, and the caretaker had his wife and another Indian woman to help and they cleaned all they thought was right for them to clean. The caretaker denied stealing
stealing anything from the school. The Agent states that the caretaker is a respectable Indian, about sixty-five years of age and he and his wife are both above the average Parry Island Indian. He receives $20.00 a year for looking after the school. He looks after the furnace, sweeps out the school and scrubs it out two or three times a year. He says he paid the woman who helped his wife to scrub $2.00 and yet this teacher has so much to say about him. She would not allow him to heat the water for scrubbing in her kitchen and so he had to make a fire outside. The Agent says that she is getting in wrong with the Indians, first accusing the missionary of pocketing receipts from the telephone and now accusing the caretaker of stealing out of the school.

The Agent states that he has done all he can to make it pleasant for her, but she has no control or discipline over the children and they are doing pretty much as they like around the school, breaking windows, etc.

The teacher does not wish the caretaker around the school at all and she is asking for the keys of the basement and the Agent says that he cannot see any chance of fixing things up with her and that she is making trouble among the Indians and taking sides with a certain troublesome faction.

She asked for a copy of the Agent's report, which was not sent her.
The Agent enclosed a letter from the Chief, in which he states that he is sorry to learn that the teacher has refused to allow the caretaker to do his work. The Chief says the caretaker is a good man and does more work than he should do. He also says that the teacher is making trouble and that he thinks the best thing to do is to discharge her.

Judging from the many long letters which Miss Watson has written the Department it is doubtful whether she will ever make a success of this school, as she does not appear to be willing to adapt herself to her surroundings. Her letters are badly expressed and indiscreet in terms. It would be to the advantage of all concerned if she would act on the suggestion conveyed to her in the Department's letter of the 19th ultimo, which was to send in her resignation if she was not satisfied with the conditions at the Ryerson School.

Miss Watson hasn't been as successful as I had anticipated when I visited the school last term. She evidently hasn't thrown sufficient energy into her work.

IN THE MATTER OF Miss Viola V. Watson, School Teacher on Parry Island Reserve.

PETITION
In the Matter of the petition of the Parry Island Indians for the retention of Miss Watson as teacher of the Indian school at Parry Island.

To Wit:

J. Andrew Watson,
of the Reserve of Parry Island,
District of Parry Sound.

Do Solemnly Declare, that

1. That I signed the petition hereunto attached and presented the petition to the different persons whose names appear thereon.

2. That all those whose names appear on the said petition stated to me that they were in favour of the prayer of same and authorized me to sign their names to the said petition, which I did.

AND I make this solemn Declaration conscientiously believing it to be true, and knowing that it is of the same force and effect as if made under oath and by virtue of the Canada Evidence Act.

DECLARED before me at the Town of Parry Sound
in the District of Parry Sound,
this 10th day of May A.D. 1918.

Andrew Watson
The Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

At the request of Mr. Andrew Walker, of Parry Island Reserve, we are enclosing herewith a petition circulated on the Reserve, asking the Department's intervention in the matter of retaining the services of Miss Watson, teacher of the Indian school at Parry Island.

When Mr. Walker returned the petition we noted that it had been apparently signed by all parties in the same handwriting, and Mr. Watson informed us that he did not understand that it was necessary to be signed by the petitioners themselves, but he assures us that he explained the petition to all those purporting to sign and they all signified their assent to the same, and authorized him to sign in their behalf.

We have had a declaration made by him and attached to the petition setting out these facts.

Yours truly,

WEEKS & JACKSON,
Per

Dear Mr. Scott,

Your kind offer of help is bringing a speedy response.

In visiting Parry Island I found a rather bad condition. It seems that the mission house is not in good condition and the Rev. Mr. Black went to live with a Mrs. Thos. C. Salt, son of one of our deceased missionaries and an old friend of theirs. Some 9 years ago Mr. Salt's wife left him and she is living with another man at Alberville. I am assured that Mr. Salt has done all in his power to secure her return.

Some evil minded persons have started talk about Mr. Salt and Mr. Black which has gradually worked up to the point of a scandal. They have recently travelled across to Parry Sound together frequently when going shopping etc., but never in any clandestine way without Mr. Black's knowledge.

I have stayed here 3 days going into this matter thoroughly. I have had them before the Indian Agent, Mr. Logan, the Chairman of the District, Rev. Dr. Smith,
the Police Magistrate Mr. Moore and the Quarterly Official Board. I cannot find any foundation for the scandal excepting in gossip and believe I am correct in saying that nothing wrong has been done.

However, I think some change is necessary so that the tongue of the slanderer may be effectively stopped for it has started toward condemning Miss Harris who is living alone at the residence attached to the School. As the Mission House must have extensive repairs I have suggested that Miss Harris take Mr. Black into the School Residence for the time being. She is delighted with the idea as it will make life bearable for her. Mr. Logan has given me his consent for her. Mr. Logan has given me his consent that I present the matter to you. Mr. Black and Miss Harris are close friends anyway.

I heartily recommend this course and hope that you will see your way clear to give your authority to have the arrangement made.

Kindest regards.

If you write me send letter to Calgary. I think it might be well to write Miss Harris' party sound direct.

Yours faithfully,

Arthur Barner

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mrs. Nellie L. Wilson, who was appointed teacher of the Shawanaga Indian Day School, at a salary of $700.00 per annum and bonus, beginning duty on the 16th of February last, has sent in her resignation to take effect on the 30th instant. Her reason for resigning is that the place is too lonely.

A teacher will be required after the summer holidays at Ryerson, Parry Island, and Mr. Superintendent Logan suggests that Mrs. Wilson be transferred there and, if so, he requests to be informed as to what salary the Department would be prepared to pay her. At the present time she is in receipt of $700.00, which is entirely paid from band funds. The teacher at the Ryerson School only receives $600.00, $300.00 of which is paid from band funds and $300.00 from vote.

I would beg to recommend that Mrs. Wilson be offered the position at the Ryerson School at the same salary as is paid her at Shawanaga and that the extra amount required be provided from the school vote. She has a limited third class certificate, is a widow with two children, and the Inspector states that the pupils have made splendid progress since she took charge. He also states that he found a decided improvement in the general management of the school (Shawanaga) and that he considers Mrs. Wilson a very capable teacher, the attendance having increased considerably since his visit last fall. I think we should endeavour to retain Mrs. Wilson's services and that she be offered the Ryerson School at $700.00 and the bonus.

On the James Bay, away up in the far north, there is a Hudson's Bay Post where the Indians come to trade for furs and get in return, flour, tea, sugar and all the other things they need to live on. At this Post there was a very tiny girl whose name was Emily and whose Father and Mother had died when she was left alone with her Grandmother. This little girl was an Indian girl, and her grandmother loved her, and as she sat in the long winter nights, she thought how lonely she would be this winter, and she pondered over what heartache would happen to her if, when she grew up, she would have to go out on the trap lines and have to bear the cold. So she said, away deep down in her heart, "I won't let her."

When the sun was shining in the summer, and little Emily was running about trying to catch the sunshine shining in at the cabin door, her grandmother used to say, "What a sweet child. How can I part with her?" because by this time she had made up her mind to send her away to the Indian Residential School, away at Chapleau, on the C.P.R. But first of all, she had to get the consent of the uncles of Emily, who also loved her very much and delighted to see her playing around. They did not want her to be sent away, but her grandmother spoke to them, and told them if they loved her they would not want her to brought up to go away from them. So they said yes, and so it was for six days, they paddled, and came to Chapleau and Emily was taken to the school.

She felt very lonely for her grandmother at first, but after a while she played with the other children who were older than she was all the time she thought about her grandmother and her uncles at Hudson Bay. Then one day a new Missionary came to take charge of Chapleau School, the Rev. Mr. Gibson and his wife. Mrs. Gibson was a big man, ever six feet tall, and he came away up in the North West Territory. When he looked at Emily his heart went out to her she looked so small, and he talked to Mrs. Gibson about her and Mrs. Gibson loved her and made her the same as one of the family. So the time went on, and it came around to Christmas time, and everybody was glad and busy getting ready for Christmas and the Christmas Tree. The children were practicing Christmas songs and everybody was talking about Santa Claus, and why Emily was wondering what it was all about. The older teachers told her about it, and Mrs. Gibson told her that if she was a good girl, Santa Claus would bring her a doll because Mrs. Gibson had written a letter telling Santa Claus how someone was for her grandmother and asked him to bring her a doll the next day which was Christmas. Well, some of the children could hardly sleep that night to see Santa Claus, but Emily lay awake for a long time, and at last fell asleep. In the morning she woke with everybody laughing and all the children clapping their hands, and being very happy. Mrs. Gibson brought Emily in her nightie, and Mr. Gibson himself came over to her and said, "Santa Claus has a doll for you Emily," and sure enough there was a doll given with a red dress and she was very happy. She cuddled into the arms of Mrs. Gibson and cuddled her doll and was ever so happy.

After that Emily was happy at the school at Chapleau and attended to her lessons. Sometimes they were very hard and she thought what's the use of trying, and then Mrs. Gibson would come to her and tell her that if she wanted to be a smart girl she must study hard. She would tell her about Pauline Johnson the Indian girl who became a great poetess herself, "I will try hard and do the best I can." Emily got on well with her lessons and it came to pass after a few months Emily was the smartest girl at her lessons in all the Chapleau School.

It was about this time that Emily had a dream, and in her dream she saw Santa Claus driving in his sleigh with six reindeer and he was in a hurry. Sir,

Enclosed please find application for position as teacher for the Ryerson Indian Day School, by the present school teacher, Desmond Bolton.

Would the Department please note what Mr. Bolton states re one of his pupils passing the entrance examination. This is the second time this pupil has tried. In connection with this I have to state that at the Depot Harbour School where there are nineteen Indian children attending, there were three pupils passed their entrance without trying the examination, and one of these Indian pupils had the highest marks of any pupil in the school.

I would suggest to the Department that they discuss Mr. Bolton's application to continue to teach with Mr. McGookin, Inspector of Indian Agencies. Mr. Bolton seems to have a pretty fair opinion of himself. I am sorry to state that neither the Indians nor myself have such a good opinion of him as a teacher, and the fact that three pupils have passed the entrance without trying the examination goes to show that it is possible to teach these children a lot better at the Ryerson School than is being done at the present time.

When Mr. Bolton was sent here by the late Mr. Ferrier, it was because he was out of a position and to help him tide over the depression. We found it necessary when Mr. Bolton came here to have him go to the public schools here to get in touch with the method of teaching. The Inspector of Schools in this District Mr. Moore informs me that in his opinion he will never make a teacher.
When one considers the number of qualified teachers who are looking for schools it is just too bad that we cannot get some of them to teach in the Ryerson Indian Day School.

I know that the Department states it is customary for the teachers to continue if they have been found satisfactory. This is a situation where the Department and the Agent should co-operate for the well being of the children of the Reserve.

I would appreciate the co-operation of the Department in seeing that we get a qualified teacher for the Ryerson Indian Day School, at the earliest convenience of the Department.

Sir:

Replying to yours of August 7th, 22-3-1, re Mr. Desmond Bolton, teacher of the Ryerson Indian Day School, and the question of dispensing with his services. In your letter you ask me to write to you around the first of November, I have been very busy here, but at the same time I was keeping this particular item in mind, but owing to the condition of affairs here I thought it would be all right to write at the first opportunity.

I had a conversation with the Inspector of Public Schools here re Mr. Bolton, and he is convinced that he will never make a school teacher. So far as I am concerned, he was only here one month when I knew that he would never be suitable for an Indian School in this section of the country. It takes a school teacher here on Parry Island to devote all his time to the teaching and any spare time he has, if he feels inclined, he could quite well put it in by talking to the parents about the advantages of education for the children. At the present time he is engaged in the Boy Scout Work. The sad part about it is that he is a married man with one child and rather a likeable fellow - outside of being a school teacher, and when I read him the letter from the Department he asked me if I would try and arrange for him to be kept on until the end of the June quarter.

He cannot do much more harm than he has done to the school, and owing to him being a married man with a wife and child, and owing to the almost impossibility of him getting a position at the present time I would suggest to the Department
that he be allowed to remain until the end of the June Quarter, and that he would be advised to that effect by the Department through this office and also be advised that after the end of the June Quarter his services will be no longer required. I am very sorry for Mr. Bolton, but his idea of teaching in Canada will never be a success. He was never cut out for a teacher and when the respected Mr. Farrier wrote and told me to do the best I could for him as he was up against it, I did so to the best of my ability, but my actions were misconstrued by Mr. Bolton. I arranged with the Department and with the Inspector of Public Schools here that he would get a few days visiting the schools and trying to catch on, and I am sorry to say that when he was through with this experience he did not have very much use for the teaching in this country. Mr. Bolton is quite well pleased with himself. His endeavours with the boy scout movement were about as successful as his teaching in the school.

I trust the Department will allow him to remain until the end of the June term when he would be better able to get a position, but that he be advised by a letter from the Department to this office, that his services after the June quarter will be no longer required.

The consideration of the Department in this matter will be appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Daly, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, requests the Department to dispense with the services of Mr. Desmond Bolton, teacher of the Ryerson Indian Day School, on the Parry Island Reserve, No. 16, Federal District of Parry Sound. Dear Sir;

Yours of May 18th, 22-3-1, received, in which you ask for a full report regarding the work of Miss Annie McArthur as teacher of the Ryerson Indian Day School.

In reply I have to state that in my opinion it is a mistake to have a person with such high qualifications teaching in an Indian Day School. I have had them before and they were not satisfactory.

I had an interview with Mr. J.L. Moore, Inspector of Public Schools in this district, and asked him how he thought Miss McArthur was getting along. He said that this was the best year she had had. I sent word to Miss McArthur that I wanted to talk to her, had a conversation with her, and apparently she is quite satisfied with herself. In yesterday's mail I received the enclosed resignation and I think it would be advisable for the Department to accept it.

I would suggest to the Department, in the event of them choosing a teacher for this school, which according to their letter they intend to do, to try to impress on the teacher for this school to look upon the teaching here from a missionary point of view. That is, the teacher should get around
and visit and get acquainted with the parents. In that way it would be better for the children, teacher, and everyone. The Indians in this section of the country are very sensitive to the "high-hatting" teachers we sometimes have here. My experience in this Agency is, that after a teacher is about three years in an Indian School in this District, they are worse than useless.

Will the department please reply at their earliest accepting Miss McArthur's resignation so that I can let her know that her resignation is officially accepted by the Department.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:-

I have been keeping up inquiries for a teacher for the Ryerson Indian Day School, but up to date without any success.

It has occurred to me that in default of obtaining a teacher for this school, we might have the children on the Reserve attend the public school at Depot Harbour. There has been a considerable falling off in the population of the village, owing to the cessation of work there by the Canadian National Railways, and inquiries I have made show that the school is sufficiently staffed and could accommodate at least thirty pupils from the Reserve, which is about the average attendance at the Ryerson School. This would entail an expenditure of .10¢ a head per day which in itself would not equal the expenses of our own school. It might however be necessary to supply transportation daily, as the distance covered by some of the pupils would be almost three miles one way. I have not gone definitely into this feature as yet but believe that if the scheme meets with your approval, I might be able to make arrangements with a local man for transportation.

Your early consideration of this matter will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

February has been marked by an epidemic of 'Flu or Grippe all over the country and the Indians have not escaped, but as usual, have had rather more than their share. School attendance has been very poor and in some cases schools had to be closed owing to illness of both teacher and pupils. I have been glad to learn that we are to have a teacher for the Ryerson School on the Parry Island Reserve, which is now scheduled to reopen on March 4. This school has been closed since last June and a good many of the youngster have been running wild, although many who live near enough to the Village of Depot Harbour have been attending the white school there. This school suspension will perhaps help the parents to realize the benefits offered by the Department's schools and induce them to more urgently take advantage of such benefits.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON PARRY SOUND INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1943.

School attendance has been more than usually bad during the winter, due largely to the exceptional snow fall and cold weather. I am glad to be able to note that during the month a teacher was obtained for the Ryerson day school on the Parry Island Reserve. This school had been closed since last June and as it serves a good number of pupils, I am glad to see it in action again. There is a scheme on foot also to have the school buildings on the Lower French Reserve moved from their present site on Jontin Island over to the mainland, which, if we can manage it, should make an improvement in the school attendance at that point.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

In confirmation of the conversation I had with you this morning I have the honor of making an application for the position of a teacher in the Bay School of Parry Island.

The particulars concerning my character, education and qualifications for this position are as follows:

I was born in Rostov on Don, Russia, on August 30th, 1901. From 1908 to 1919 I attended a private classical school (gymnasium) there and graduated with a gold medal.

In 1919 I registered in the Department of Physics and Mathematics of the Don University (Rostov on Don) but due to the Revolution was able to stay there only one semester.

From the beginning of 1920 to the end of 1921 I served in the White Army fighting the communists.

At the end of 1921 I went to Prague, Czechoslovakia and registered in the Electrical Engineering Department of the Polytechnic Institute of Prague. I stayed there until the end of 1924 and then came to the United States to continue my studies at Union College, Schenectady, New York.
I graduated from the Union College in 1927 with honors and received the degree of B.S. in Electrical Engineering. From 1927 to 1930 I worked in the Switchgear and Testing Departments of the General Electric Company at Schenectady, etc., and at the same time studied for the degree of M.S. in Electrical Engineering. I received this degree in 1937 upon submission of a thesis.

In 1930 I was admitted to Canada and joined the firm of Canadian & General Finance Company, 25 King St. West, Toronto, Ontario. I worked in the Electrical Engineering Department of this firm in the capacity of an engineer until the end of 1945 when I resigned for personal reasons.

I was born in and belong to the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church. Besides English and Russian, I read French and Czech and have a slight knowledge of German and Portuguese.

At the time of my graduation from the Union College I was elected to membership in Eta Kappa Nu, honorary electrical engineering society, and associate membership in Sigma Xi, honorary scientific society.

I am a member of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, Association of Professional Engineers of Ontario and Royal Canadian Institute.

I became a British subject on May 16th, 1936, certificate #141946, series A.
