Dear Phil,

As you no doubt know, I spent a holiday at Appinwood Beach this summer and while I was there I was approached by a member of the Kettle Point Indians with a view to securing my return to that School. Now that I have returned here since I left this same request had been made, but it was not until this year that I felt free to make a move from Toronto. I agreed with the chief that the Department be rounded out only after assurance that the Indian Agent was fully aware of the circumstances that culminated in my earlier resignation and was personally agreeable to my return. I was assured on both these conditions. I understand that the Department was approached and felt that the request of the Band could not be accepted. I left the matter at that.

I returned the other day to spend a couple of weeks with some friends here and found that the Indians had gone further and circulated a petition that the matter be reconsidered. I saw Mr. McClellan and he confirmed this to me.
adding that in conversation with Mr. Mitchell he had been informed that the Department felt no change could be made in their decision so far as the Little Poveshiek School was concerned.

I can assure you that there would be no further embarrassment to the Department from my presence at the School and I have Mr. McEachin's assurance that over ninety percent of the Indians favour my return. However, if this is absolutely out of the question I understand that the Emma School is vacant and you might consider that for the time being.

I am anxious to leave this city and return to Kootenay. I find the work and surroundings much more congenial. I am writing you personally therefore, to ascertain just what the position is exactly. If you could drop me a personal note then I would be extremely grateful.

At a meeting of the Parry Island Band Council held on December 14 the following resolution was passed.

Moved by Peter Judge,
Seconded by Stanley Manitowaba

That in view of the critical situation with regard to the Parry Island Day School having been without a teacher for some time, this Council believes that the regulations should be relaxed to permit the appointment of a Catholic teacher if it is found impossible to secure one of the Protestant faith. The band membership as it now stands shows 82 protestants and 50 catholics.

The idea behind this resolution is that if we find it impossible, as we have found it up to date, to secure a protestant teacher for this point that the Indians of the Parry Island Band would be perfectly satisfied to have a catholic teacher rather than none at all. I believe that if it were possible to relax the regulations in this respect it might give us a wider field of choice.

Dear Mr. Devlin,

This is my application for the position as principal of the school on Parry Sound Island Reserve should the school be divided into two rooms.

I am an experienced and qualified teacher with a First Class Certificate from the Ontario Normal School in Hamilton. In addition I have a Strathcona Physical Training Certificate, a certificate in the Standard Leadership Curriculum course, and a St. John's First Aid Certificate. I also have to my credit 6½ majors towards a B.A. degree from McMaster University which I obtained intra-murally.

I am Protestant (United Church), thirty-two and married (my wife has her B.A. degree). I am of Irish parentage, was born in Scotland and came to Canada when I was nine years of age.
My present inspector is Mr. C. W. MacKillop B.A., B.Ped., Richmond Hill, Ontario.

I am thoroughly experienced in running a rural school since I have taught all the grades from 1 to 10.

I am not green at other types of work either since I had to earn the cost of my own education and earn my own living at the same time. To do so I worked as a sales-clerk in the J. Eaton Co., as an inspector for the American Can Co., and as a laboratory technician for the Steel Co. of Canada.

In addition to the necessary normal school, senior matriculation, and university subjects, I have studied music and art, in both of which I am credited with some ability. I have a gold medal for violin playing, and have played at many concerts over the radio, and in several orchestras. My matriculation course included Commercial Art and Machine Drafting. I am also experienced in the craft of pottery and in woodwork, both of which are hobbies of mine.
Once before, I was in the same inspectorate with Mr. MacKillop when I had the school in Whitefish in the Sudbury District. The school there increased my salary by fifty dollars after the Christmas vacation and gave me room and fuel free. I left to obtain more money so that I could advance my own education. I left my next school which had four rooms, because the former principal wished to return when he was released from the Air Force. I am leaving my present school (with which I am highly satisfied and the board of which wishes me to stay) because I need a greater income due to my married status.

I have several letters of recommendation, copies of which you may have upon request. Hoping to receive your favourable reply,

I am,

Yours very respectfully,

Walter A.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

I am enclosing applications from Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ard for the position of school teacher on the Parry Island Reserve. I have already had some correspondence with Mr. Ard as a result of advertisements which we ran for school teachers in the earlier part of the year. I had explained to him that it was our intention if possible, to make the Parry Island School a two-room institution. It will be recalled that we had discussed this last year, since the school membership roll runs between forty and fifty. As explained at that time, the present school building is inadequate for this purpose but I believe it would be possible for me to obtain a large room in a nearby house which could be, at some little expense, fitted up as a schoolroom. The principal difficulty which remained was the living quarters. Those in the present school building, however, although small, could accommodate a man and his wife. I believe that this would be our best solution for Parry Island where for several years now we have experienced great difficulty in obtaining and retaining teachers.

I am definitely advised by the present teacher, Mrs. Edith Rail that it is her intention to return to Scotland after the summer holidays and that she does not now expect to come back.

The only fault which I can find with Mr. Ard's application is that his qualifications seem to be high for the position. I would be glad if you would correspond with him direct, advising him as to the probable salaries for himself and his wife, keeping me in touch with what is being done.

Inspector of Schools Cassie makes the following comments in his report on the above school:

"Re Building - Some minor repairs and interior decorating are desirable.

"Attendance - Has been fairly regular. Several have taken work for the summer hence many away today.

"Department - Satisfactory at time of inspection.

"Teaching - Individual items are well enough taught but general procedure leaves much to be desired. This teacher does not plan, and arrange, sufficient seatwork. When she is teaching one grade all others are listening or are idle. Progress must necessarily be retarded under this procedure. Many classes would soon become unmanageable unless kept busier than are these pupils.

"Pupils' Work - Progress would appear to be spotty. Some are doing fairly well, while others are more or less lost. Oral answers are fairly well given. Written work is rather poor; a higher standard might be required. Vocal music has been well taught; the children sing heartily and in tune.

"It appears to me as though this teacher tries very hard - it might be an improvement if she so arranged her programme that she were doing less and the children more.

Ottawa, August 7th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing an application which you received from Miss Edith H. Smiley for the position as teacher of the Ryerson Indian Day School, and stating the qualifications and experience which she possesses and the salary required.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Smiley to begin duties when the school re-opens after the present summer holidays, on September 2nd, next. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $700 per annum, supplemented by the bonus provided by law. The bonus for the present fiscal year ending March 31st, 1925, will be at the rate of $15 per teaching month. Payment of both salary and bonus is based on ten teaching months in the year.

Kindly inform Miss Smiley of the approval of her appointment and ascertain definitely from her whether she will accept the position or not, and advise the Department of her decision.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Ottawa, August 18, 1924.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your telegram, accepting the position of teacher at the Ryerson Indian Day School. I take it for granted that you are Protestant. If not, I should be pleased to hear from you without delay. Mr. Indian Agent Daly, of Parry Sound, is being informed of your appointment. The salary will be at the rate of $700 for the ten teaching months, plus any bonus provided by law. At present there is a bonus of $15 per teaching month paid to teachers of Indian day schools.

I should be pleased if, upon the occasion of your next visit to Ottawa, you would call at the Department - the Schools Branch, Room 501, Booth Building. Instructions and advice will be given to you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Miss Edith H. Smiley,
Wright,
Que.
Ottawa, August 21st, 1926.

Sir:

Relative to conversation with you while in the Department yesterday regarding an increase in salary to Miss Edith Smiley, I beg to say that the Department will approve of an increase of $5 per teaching month from the 1st of September, next. This will make her salary from that date at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

Please inform Miss Smiley of the increase granted, which is made in view of the excellent services which she has performed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

John M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Ottawa, July 24, 1931.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has appointed Mr. Desmond Bolten to the position of teacher of the Ryerson Indian Day School - salary to be at the rate of $65 per teaching month. Mr. Bolten is a 26 year old Irishman, is married and has one 2 year old child. He expects to reach Parry Sound during the week prior to the opening of school on September first and, of course, will report to your office. You will please give him every possible help as he commences his new duties. Mr. Bolten has no Canadian professional qualifications, but his training at Queen's University, Belfast, and general experience have, I believe, fitted him for this post. He is very highly recommended by those who know him in Ottawa. He came to Canada in 1926 and three years ago married an Ottawa girl.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. H. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

The Secretary,
Department Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Enclosed please find Day School reports for the quarter ending September for this Agency, for Moose Point, Parry Island, Shawanaga, Magnetawan and Lower French.

I find these reports very satisfactory, so early in the season, and have reason to believe that they will be satisfactory in the coming quarter.

I have made arrangements and received programmes for the teacher's convention which will be held in Parry Sound and have sent same to the teachers, and because of this, as I understand the teachers have not too much money, I would respectfully request that the Department send forward the cheques at their earliest convenience, so that the teachers may be able to attend the convention on the 8th and 9th of October.

If I receive the cheques by the 5th, the teachers in the various reserves will be able to get them by the 7th, which would give them a chance to attend the convention.

I am very anxious that the teachers should attend for the reason that I would like the people and the teachers in this district to realize that my teachers are in as good standing as they are. In this way we are able to cast a good impression on the district regarding our efforts to have qualified teachers in our schools.
The earnest consideration of the Department in this matter will be very much appreciated, very much, by the teachers and myself.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Referring to previous correspondence, in connection with securing a teacher for the Ryerson Indian Day School for the coming academic year, to succeed Mr. Desmond Bolton, whose services have been dispensed with, I have to inform you the Honourable the Minister has directed that Miss Annie McArthur, B.A., of Parry Sound, is to be engaged for the coming school year. I would request that you give Miss McArthur every possible assistance in her work at this school.

Your obedient servant,

At a meeting of the Council of the Parry Island Band yesterday the 1st, which I attended, a resolution was passed asking the Department to grant its approval of the purchase of a bell for the Lyndon School House. Sir,

Referring to your letter of August 1st in which you authorized an expenditure of $50.00 to repair the mission school on the Parry Island near I beg to inform you that I have found it impossible to secure anyone who would undertake to do what is required to be done for this sum.

I have found on making an examination of the school house that the following repairs are absolutely necessary:

- Roof of school house sloped re-shingled
- Porch sheathed inside
- Ceilings & Walls replastered & whitewashed
- New floor & supports under joists
- Painting inside woodwork - to include wainscoting, window casings & seat

The only man in Parry Sound who will undertake to make the above repairs is Simon Woods & he asks to complete the work for $75.00.

I would suggest that this work be done during the summer holidays as it is badly needed. I would recommend that Simon Woods offer be accepted.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Maclean
Indian Agent

MEMORANDUM.

The school building and teacher's residence at Parry Island required some slight repairs, which have been made since my return.

I spoke to the Chief and Indians regarding their complaints against Miss Armour, their teacher, and told them that they should try and make things pleasant for her instead of making it as disagreeable as possible and that they had no right to ask for her resignation. They promised me that they would try to get along better in future. Mr. Agent Macdonald told me the trouble was that Mr. Elias, who is teacher of the Indian school at Shawinaga, was anxious to be placed in charge of the Parry Island school and that the Indians were trying to get rid of Miss Armour to make a vacancy for him. Mr. Macdonald said it would be unwise to give Mr. Elias this school in any event. I think that there will be no more trouble about Miss Armour in future.

The school is centrally located and the teacher's quarters will be quite comfortable when the new porch is
put up. These Indians are well-to-do and should be quite happy and contented.

Ryerson Indian School, Parry Island Reserve

This school is in charge of Miss Armour, who holds a Third Class Provincial Certificate. She has been teaching in this school about seven years.

The pupils who have attempted to regular attendance have made good progress. The greater portion of the pupils attending this school are children of non-members of the band. For some unstated reason, the Chief and others of the Band are clamouring for the removal of the present teacher, and they refuse from sending their children to school. The discontented agitators are mostly persons that have no school age children. The boys when they reach the age of twelve quit attending school. Excepting a rare case, the girls attend up to sixteen and seventeen years of age, and are much improved in intelligence and moral character, and adapt themselves to cleanliness and taste, surpassing many of their white neighbors.

The school house neat, warm and comfortable, well aired. The wood for the school is stored in a new and substantial wood shed built last fall, which adds much to the saving of fuel. The outside conveniences should be built further away from the school room door. It should also be further apart. As the present closets are in such shape they are worth improving.

The teacher's residence has been improved by a storm porch, which has added much comfort to the kitchen. The interior of this house requires painting, such as the floor, stairway, doors, and window casings and the wainscoting. Would give the interior an air of cleanliness and an exemplary inducement for the Indians to imitate and keep up.

Sir,

I beg to enclose to you a copy of minutes of Parry Island Council meeting held on Aug. 3rd.

In regard to motion No. 1 new school house, I may say that the present school is in very bad shape. It is a log building, built 35 years ago, and is not worth spending any more money to keep it in repair. The school and teacher's house are too close to the railway track and I think it would be much better to have house and school in one. It certainly has its advantage in cold weather. We can get a very nice site for new school if the Department decide to build and I would recommend that a nice building be put up at a cost of, say $3000.

I am Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM,

Mr. Scott.

Mr. Superintendent Logan encloses a resolution of the Council of the Parry Island Band for the erection of a combined school-house and teacher's residence for the Ryerson School. Sir,

I beg to inform you that plans and specifications have been prepared for a combined school and teachers residence for Ryerson School, Parry Island, Ont., for which tenders have been requested by advertisement in the Daily Mail and Empire, Toronto, The World, Toronto, The Canadian Echo, Owen Sound, The Mirror, Meaford, The Enterprise Messenger, Collingwood, The News, Toronto.

Plans and specifications are being sent you by concurrent post under separate registered cover. You are requested to kindly take charge of them and allow any one desiring to tender, to examine them for that purpose.

Tenders will close at noon on the eighth day of June next after which date, you are requested to return the plans and specifications to the Department by Registered Post.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th inst., advising me that you have sent plans and specifications for a wheel at Parry Island, Ont., and asking me to take charge of same until after the tenders are closed. The plans and specifications referred to were received here today. I was just wondering if you did not intend this letter and the plans etc., to go to the Postmaster at Parry Sound, instead of Owen Sound. I also notice in the list of papers in which you are advertising for tenders, you have one "The Canadian Echo, Owen Sound." This is also an error as we have no paper of that name here, but there is one by that name published in Wiarton. You will I know pardon me for making this correction, and if it is the Department's intention that they be put on exhibition in this Office I will be very pleased to carry out your instructions.

Yours obediently,
